WHEN THE ORBIT ALGEBRA OF GROUP IS AN INTEGRAL
DOMAIN? PROOF OF A CONJECTURE OF P.J. CAMERON
MAURICE POUZET
Abstract. P.J.Cameron introduced the orbit algebra of a permutation group and
conjectured that this algebra is an integral domain if and only if the group has no
nite orbit. We prove that this conjecture holds and in fact that the age algebra of a
relational structure R is an integral domain if and only if R is age-inexhaustible. We
deduce these results from a combinatorial lemma asserting that if a product of two
non-zero elements of a set algebra is zero then there is a nite common tranversal of
their supports. The proof is built on Ramsey theorem and the integrity of a shue
algebra.
Introduction
In 1981, P.J.Cameron [4] (see also [9] p.86) associated a graded algebra A[G] to a
permutation group G acting on an innite set E. He formulated two conjectures on
the integrity of this algebra. The purpose of this paper is to present a solution to the
rst of these conjectures. Consequences on the enumeration of nite substructures of
a given structure are mentionned. Some problems are stated.
0.1. The conjectures. Here is the content of these conjectures, freely adapted from
Camerons web page (see Problem 2 [10]). The graded algebra A[G] is the direct sum

As shown by Cameron, the constant function e in A[G]1 (with value 1 on every one
element set) is not a zero-divisor (see Theorem 0.8 below). The group G is entire if
A[G] is an integral domain, and strongly entire if A[G]/eA[G] is an integral domain.

MAURICE POUZET
Conjectures 0.1. G is (strongly) entire if and only if it has no nite orbit on E.
The condition that G has no nite orbit on E is necessary. We prove that it suces
for G to be entire. As it turns out, our proof extends to the algebra of an age, also
invented by Cameron [10].
0.2. The algebra of an age. A relational structure is a realization of a language
whose non-logical symbols are predicates. This is a pair R := (E, (i)iI) made of a
set E and a family of mi-ary relations i on E. The set E is the domain or base of
R; the family  := (mi)iI is the signature of R. The substructure induced by R on
a subset A of E, simply called the restriction of R to A, is the relational structure
RA := (A, (Ami  i)iI). Notions of isomorphism, as well as isomorphic type, are
dened in natural way (see Subsection 1.1).
A map f : [E]m  C, where m is a non negative integer, is R-invariant if f (P ) =
f (P ) whenever the restrictions R|P and R|P  are isomorphic. The R-invariant maps
Indeed, it is not dicult to show that if f : [E]m  C and
can be multiplied.
g : [E]n  C are R-invariant, the product dened by Equation (1) is R-invariant.
Equipped with this multiplication, the C-vector space spanned by the R-invariant
maps becomes a graded algebra, the age algebra of R, that we denote by C.A(R).
The name, coined by Cameron, comes from the notion of age dened by Frasse [13].
Indeed, the age of R is the collection A(R) of substructures of R induced on the
nite subsets of R, isomorphic substructures being identied. And it can be shown
that two relational structures with the same age yields the same algebra (up to an
isomorphism of graded algebras).
The algebra associated to a group is a special case of age algebra. Indeed, to a
permutation group G acting on E we may associate a relational structure R with
base E such that the G-invariant maps coincide with the R-invariant maps.
Our criterium for the integrity of the age algebra is based on the notion of kernel:
The kernel of a relational structure R is the subset K(R) of x  E such that
The emptyness of the kernel R is a necessary condition for the integrity of the
age algebra. Indeed, if K(R) 6= , pick x  K(R) and F  [E] such that RF
A(R) \ A(R|E\{x}). Let P  [E]. Set f (P ) := 1 if RP is isomorphic to RF ,
otherwise set f (P ) := 0. Then f 2 := f f = 0.
Theorem 0.2. Let R be a relational structure with possibly innitely many non iso-
morphic types of n-element substructures. The age algebra C.A(R) is an integral
domain if and only if the kernel of R is empty.
The application to the conjecture of Cameron is immediate. Let G be a permutation
group acting on E and let R be a relational structure encoding G. Then, the kernel
of R is the union of the nite G-orbits of the one-element sets. Thus, if G has no
nite orbit, the kernel of R is empty. Hence from Theorem 0.2, A[G] is an integral
domain, as conjectured by Cameron.
We deduce Theorem 0.2 from a combinatorial property of a set algebra over a eld
(Theorem 0.3 below). This property does not depends upon the eld, provided that
its characteristic is zero. The proof we give in Section 1.1 is an extension of our
A CONJECTURE OF P.J. CAMERON
1970 proof that the prole of an innite relational structure does not decrease (see
Theorem 0.5 below). The key tool we used then was Ramseys theorem presented in
terms of a property of almost-chainable relations. Here, these relations are replaced by
F  L-invariant relational structures, structures which appeared, under other names,
in several of our papers (see [24], [25], [27]). The nal step is reminiscent of the proof
of the integrity of a shue algebra.
We introduced the notion of kernel in[24] and studied it in several papers [25] [26],
[27] and [29]. As it is easy to see (cf [25][29]), the kernel of a relational structure
R is empty if and only if for every nite subset F of E there is a disjoint subset F
such that the restrictions R|F and R|F  are isomorphic. Hence, relational structures
with empty kernel are those for which their age has the disjoint embedding property,
meaning that two arbitrary members of the age can be embedded into a third in
such a way that their domain are disjoint. In Frasses terminology, ages with the
disjoint embedding property are said inexhaustible and relational structures whose
age is inexhaustible are said age-inexhaustible; we say that relational structures with
nite kernel are almost age-inexhaustible. 1
0.3. A transversality property of the set algebra. Let K be a eld with charac-
teristic zero. Let E be a set and let [E] be the set of nite subsets of E (including
the empty set ). Let K[E] be the set of maps f : [E]  K. Endowed with the
usual addition and scalar multiplication of maps, this set is a vector space over K.
Let f, g  K[E] and Q  [E]. Set:

With this operation added, the above set becomes a K-algebra. This algebra is
commutative and it has a unit, denoted by 1. This is the map taking the value 1
on the empty set and the value 0 everywhere else. The set algebra is the subalgebra
made of maps f such that f (P ) = 0 for every P  [E] with |P | large enough.
This algebra is graded, the homogeneous component of degree n being made of maps
which take the value 0 on every subset of size dierent from n (see Cameron [6]). If
f and g belong to two homogeneous components, their product is given by Equation
(1), thus an age algebra, or a group algebra, A, as previously dened, is a subalgebra
of this set algebra. The set algebra is far from to be an integral domain. But, with
the notion of degree, the integrity of A will reduce to the fact that if m and n are
two non negative integers and f : [E]m  K, f : [E]n  K are two non-zero maps
belonging to A, their product f g is non zero.

cardinalities (possibly innite) of transversals of H. We make the convention that

which inexhaustibility, resp. almost inexhaustibility, is used for relational structures with empty,

MAURICE POUZET

not, then  (supp(f )  supp(g))  t.

integral domain there are two non-zero maps f : [E]m  K, f : [E]n  K belonging
to K.A(R), whose product f g is zero. Since K is an integral domain, none of the in-

of R is empty, it turns out that  (supp(f )) is innite. Hence  (supp(f )  supp(g)) is
innite, contradicting the conclusion of Theorem 0.3.
An other immediate consequence of Theorem 0.3 is the fact, due to Cameron, that
on an innite set E, e is not a zero-divisor (see Theorem 0.8 below).

0.4. Age algebra and prole of a relational structure. The group agebra was
invented by Cameron in order to study the behavior of the function G which counts
for each integer n the number G(n) of orbits of n-subsets of a set E on which acts a
permutation group G, a function that we call the orbital prole of G. Groups for which
the orbital prole takes only nite values are quite important. Called oligomorphic
groups by Cameron, they are an objet of study by itself (see Camerons book[5]).
We present rst some properties of the prole, a counting function somewhat more
general. Next, we present the link with the age algebra, then we gives an illustration
of Theorem 0.2. We conclude with some problems.
A CONJECTURE OF P.J. CAMERON
0.4.1. Prole of a relational structure. The prole of a relational structure R with
base E is the function R which counts for every integer n the number (possibly
innite) R(n) of substructures of R induced on the n-element subsets, isomorphic
substructures being identied. Clearly, if R encodes a permutation groups G, R(n)
is the number G(n) of orbits of n-element subsets of E.
If the signature  is nite (in the sense that I is nite), there are only nitely
many relational structures with signature  on an n-element domain, hence R(n) is
necessarily an integer for each integer n. In order to capture examples coming from
algebra and group theory, one cannot preclude I to be innite. But then, R(n) could
be an innite cardinal. As far as one is concerned by the behavior of R, this case
can be excluded:

If R(n) is innite then R(n + 1) is innite too and R(n)  R(n + 1).

Let m, n,  be three non-negative integers and E be an -element set. Let Mn,n+m

Theorem 0.7. If 2n+ m  l then Mn,n+m has full row rank (over the eld of rational

Theorem 0.7 is in W.Kantor 1972 [19], with similar results for ane and vector
subspaces of a vector space. Over the last 30 years, it as been applied and redis-
covered many times; recently, it was pointed out that it appeared in a 1966 paper

combinatorics. A proof, with a clever argument leading to further developments, was
given by Frasse in the 1986s edition of his book, Theory of relations, see [13].
MAURICE POUZET
We proved Theorem 0.6 in 1976 [23]. The same conclusion was obtained rst
for orbits of nite permutation groups by Livingstone and Wagner, 1965 [20], and
extended to arbitrary permutation groups by Cameron, 1976 [3]. His proof uses the
dual version of Theorem 0.7. Later on, he discovered a nice translation in terms of
his age algebra, that we present now.
For that, observe that R only depends upon the age of R and, moreover, if R take
only integer values, then K.A(R) identies with the set of (nite) linear combinations
of members of A(R). In this case, as pointed out by Cameron, R(n) is the dimension
of the homogeneous component of degree n of K.A(R).
Let e  K[E]

elsewhere. Let U be the subalgebra generated by e. We can think of e as the sum of

Theorem 0.8. If R is innite then, for every u  K.A(R), eu = 0 if and only if

0.4.2. Growth rate of the prole. Innite relational structures with a constant prole,
equal to 1, were called monomorphic and characterized by R. Frasse who proved that
they were chainable. Later on, those with bounded prole, called nimorphic, were
characterized as almost chainable [14]. Groups with orbital prole equal to 1 were
described by P.Cameron in 1976 [3]. From his characterization, Cameron obtained
that an orbital prole is ultimately constant, or grows as fast as a linear function with
slope 1
The age algebra can be also used to study the growth of the prole.
If A is a graded algebra, the Hilbert function hA of A is the function which associates
to each integer n the dimension of the homogeneous component of degree n. So,
provided that it takes only nite values, the prole R is the Hilbert function of the
age algebra C.A(R).
In [10], Cameron made the following important observation
about the behavior of the Hilbert fonction.
Theorem 0.9. Let A be a graded algebra over an algebraically closed eld of charac-
teristic zero. If A is an integral domain the values of the Hilbert function hA satisfy
the inequality
hA(n) + hA(m)  1  hA(n + m)
for all non-negative integers n and m.
This result has an immediate consequence on the growth of the prole:
Theorem 0.10. [26] The growth of the prole of a relational structure with empty
kernel is at least linear provided that it is unbounded.
A CONJECTURE OF P.J. CAMERON
In fact, provided that the relational structures satisfy some mild conditions, the
existence of jumps in the behavior of the prole extends.

Theorem 0.11. Let R := (E, (i)iI) be a relational structure. The growth of R
is either polynomial or as fast as every polynomial provided that either the signature
:= (ni)iI is bounded or the kernel K(R) of R is nite.
Theorem 0.11 is in [24]. An outline of the proof is given in [28]. A part appeared in
[26], with a detailed proof showing that the growth of unbounded proles of relational
structures with bounded signature is at least linear.
The kernel of any relational structure which encodes an oligomorphic permutation
group is nite (indeed, as already mentionned, if R encodes a permutation group G
acting on a set E then K(R) is the set union of the nite orbits of the one-element
subsets of E. Since the number of these orbits is at most G(1), K(R) is nite if G is
oligomorphic). Hence:
Corollary 0.12. The orbital prole of an oligomorphic group is either polynomial or
faster than every polynomial.
For groups, and graphs, there is a much more precise result than Theorem 0.11. It
is due to Macpherson, 1985 [22].
Theorem 0.13. The prole of a graph or a permutation groups grows either as a
polynomial or as fast as f, where f(n) = en

Remark 0.14. Since the prole is non-decreasing, if R(n) is a quasi-polynomial for
n large enough then ak(n) is eventually constant. Hence the prole has polynomial
growth in the sense that R(n)  cnk for some positive real c and k  N. Thus, in

A special case was solved positively with N.Thiery [30].
These problems are linked with the structure of the age algebra.
Indeed, if a
graded algebra A is nitely generated, then, since A is a quotient of a polynomial
ring K[x1, . . . , xd], its Hilbert function is bounded above by a polynomial. And, in
fact, as it is well known, its Hilbert series is a fraction of form P (x)
(1x)d , thus of the form
given in (6). Moreover, one can choose a numerator with non-negative coecients
whenever the algebra is Cohen-Macaulay. Due to Problem 2, one could be tempted
to conjecture that these sucient conditions are necessary in the case of age agebras.
Indeed, from Theorem 0.8 one deduces easily:
Theorem 0.15. The prole of R is bounded if and only if K.A(R) is nitely generated
as a module over U, the graded algebra generated by e. In particular, if one of these
equivalent conditions holds, K.A(R) is nitely generated
But this case is exceptional. The conjecture can be disproved with tournaments.
Indeed, on one hand, there are tournaments whose prole has arbitrarily large poly-
nomial growth rate and, on an other hand, the age algebra of a tournament is nitely
generated if and only if the prole of the tournament is bounded (this result was
obtained with N.Thiery, a proof is presented in [28]).
0.4.4. Initial segments of an age and ideals of a ring. No concrete description of
relational structures with bounded signature, or nite kernel, which have polynomial
growth is known. In [24] (see also [28]) we proved that if a relational structure R
has this property then its age, A(R), is well-quasi-ordered under embeddability, that
is every nal segment of A(R) is nitely generated, which amounts to the fact that
the collection F (A(R)) of nal segments of A(R) is noetherian, w.r.t. the inclusion
order. Since the fundamental paper of Higman[17], applications of the notion of
well-quasi-ordering have proliferated (eg see the Robertson-Seymours theorem for an
application to graph theory [11] ). Final segments play for posets the same role than
ideals for rings. Noticing that an age algebra is nitely generated if and only if it is
noetherian, we are lead to have a closer look at the relationship between the basic
objects of the theory of relations and of ring theory, particularly ages and ideals.
We mention the following result which will be incorporated into a joint paper with
N.Thiery.
A CONJECTURE OF P.J. CAMERON
Proposition 0.16. Let A be the age of a relational structure R such that the prole
of R takes only nite values and K.A be its age algebra. If A is an initial segment
of A then:
(i) The vector subspace J := K.(A \ A) spanned by A \ A is an ideal of K.A.
Moreover, the quotient of K.A by J is a ring isomorphic to the ring K.A.
(ii) If this ideal is irreducible then A is a subage of A.
(iii) This is a prime ideal if and only if A is an inexhaustible age.
The proof of Item (i) and Item (ii) are immediate. The proof of Item (iii) is
essentially based on Theorem 0.2.
According to Item (i), F (A) embeds into the collection of ideals of K.A). Conse-
quently:
Corollary 0.17. If an age algebra is nitely generated then the age is well-quasi-
ordered by embeddability.
Problem 4. How the nite generation of an age algebra translates in terms of em-
beddability between members of the ages?
0.4.5. Links with language theory. In the theory of languages, one of the basic results
is that the generating series of a regular language is a rational fraction (see [1]). This
result is not far away from our considerations. Indeed, if A is a nite alphabet, with
say k elements, and A is the set of words over A, then each word can be viewed as a
nite chain coloured by k colors. Hence A can be viewed as the age of the relational
structure R made of the chain Q of rational numbers divided into k colors in such
a way that, between two distinct rational numbers, all colors appear. Moreover, as
pointed out by Cameron [6], the age algebra Q.A(R) is isomorphic to the shue
algebra over A, an important object in algebraic combinatorics (see [21]).
Problem 5. Does the members of the age of a relational structure with polynomial
growth can be coded by words forming a regular language?
Problem 6. Extend the properties of regular languages to subsets of the collection
made of isomorphic types of nite relational structures with signature .
1. Proof of Theorem 0.3
The proof idea of Theorem 0.3 is very simple and we give it rst.
We prove the result by induction. We suppose that it holds for pairs (m  1, n).
Now, let f : [E]m  K and g : [E]n  K such that f g is zero, but f and g are not.

elements A of [E]m into three colors :-,0, +, according to the value of f (A). We do the
same with elements B of [E]n and we color each member (A, B) of supp(f, g) with the
colors of its components. With the help of Ramsey theorem and a lexicographical
ordering, we prove that if the transversality is large enough there is an (m+n)-element
subset Q such that all pair (A, B)  supp(f, g)(Q) := supp(f, g)  ([Q]m  [Q]n) have

Lemma 1.1. Let K be a eld with characteristic zero. There is a partition of K :=
K \ {0} into at most four blocks such that for every integer k and every k-element

Proof. This holds trivially if K := C. For an example, divide C into the sets
Di := {z  C : i
If K is arbitrary, use the Com-
pactness theorem of rst-order logic, under the form of the diagram method of
A.Robinson [18]. Namely, to the language of elds, add names for the elements of
K, a binary predicate symbol, and axioms, this in such a way that a model, if any,
of the resulting theory T will be an extension of K with a partition satisfying the
conclusion of the lemma. According to the Compactness theorem of rst-order logic,
the existence of a model of T , alias the consistency of T , reduces to the consistency of
every nite subset A of T . A nite subset A of T leads to a nitely generated subeld
of K. Such subeld is isomorphic to a subeld of C (see [18] Example 2, p.99, or [2]
Proposition 1, p. 108). This latter subeld equipped with the partition induced by
the partition existing on C satises the conclusion of the lemma, hence is a model
of T , proving that A is consistent.
Let T be the set of these four blocks, let T := T  {0} and let  be the map from
K onto T.

from K[n+1][E] into K[n][E] induced by Df and De are equivalent.
Suppose that E is nite. In this case, the matrix of the restriction of De to K[n+1][E]
identies to Mn,n+1. Thus, according to Theorem 0.7, De is surjective provided that

Lemma 2.2. If f does not take the value zero on a subset E of E of size at least
2n + 1 but f g = 0 for some g : [E]n  K then g is zero on the n-element subsets of
E.

on each pair meeting the two squares. Then for every x  E, E \ {x} is a minimal
transversal of supp(f )  supp(g).
